byline.contributor: Jennifer Crossley Howard contributed reporting from Decatur, Ala., and Susan Beachy contributed research.
byline.original: By SERGE F. KOVALESKI and ALEXANDRA ALTER

abstract: Second narrative emerges on eve of release of Harper Lee novel Go Set a Watchman, raising questions about how book made its way to publication; publisher HarperCollins and Lee's lawyer Tonja B Carter say Carter came across novel in 2014, but rare books expert Justin Caldwell claims Carter and Lee's literary agent Samuel Pinkus first discovered novel in 2011; discrepancy between two accounts raises questions about whether book was lost and why it was not published earlier.
lead_paragraph: Evidence has emerged suggesting that “Go Set a Watchman,” said to have been discovered in August and set to be released on July 14, may have been found years earlier.

headline.main: Harper Lee’s ‘Go Set a Watchman’ May Have Been Found Earlier Than Thought
headline.print_headline: Intrigue Grows Over New Book by Harper Lee

snippet: Evidence has emerged suggesting that “Go Set a Watchman,” said to have been discovered in August and set to be released on July 14, may have been found years earlier.
